comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The corner shop at left was said to be "nearing completion" in 1909 in the Westmeath Independent, according to the NIAH

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: As can be seen at the OS map link, this is Church Street further along, but the near end is Custume Place, formerly Victoria Place. Several of the shop owners can be found in the 1911 census: e.g Campbell, Farrelly, Fleming's Medical Hall is on Church St. proper.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Charles Fair, Solicitor, has a first floor office at left.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] That NIAH date is great. I was thinking around 1910-ish. Great that the building that is [P]arson's in our photo selling K Boots is still a shoe shop today. The NIAH call this building "one of the very rare examples of an early twentieth-century shopfront with such detailing in County Westmeath".
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Pump is one of the things P is used for (along with Pillar, Pole, Post and such). I think this is a Pump, one of those wheel-operated ones, where the IRA man stands today.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Mr Fair, solicitor* of Athlone, was mentioned in the pages of Freeman's
Nov 1 1864 - representing several parties who sustained injuries in the railway accident near ballinasloe May 22 1896 - appeared for a Mr Mackay in support of his application to the Inspectors or Irish Fisheries. Mr Mackay wanted to extend the season for eel fishing in the Shannon to include February. Jan 6 1896 - A Mr Fair of Athlone, acting as "agent for the Atwell estate, attended in the White Hart Hotel, Omagin, on Saturday last, to collect the rents in Seaskinshale, Mullaghain, and other townlands comprised in the estate." In addition (Aug 1895) an R.J.Fair of Athlone finished third in the 440yds Flat Handicap (Open) at Ballinasloe Athletic Sports
*surely with a name like that he (or perhaps they) should have been a judge

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: That is a hoot! When I looked at [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley]'s Streetview, spotted the modern Burgess shopfront and it rang bells. It was one of the shops given a makeover on Feargal Quinn's Retail Therapy...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The 1911 census shows a 39-year-old Charles E Fair in Athlone. I imagine there was a Fair soliciting dynasty. I wonder if they were related to the solicitor Henry Fair who practised in Dublin in the late 19th century.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] John, the 1864 mention in the Freeman's Journal must have been Charles Fair's father. By the looks of the 1911 census, "our" Charles was born around 1872...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Fair and Murtagh still there in Athlone. Their history page metions no Fairs before Charles E, and There are no Fairs on the current staff. C.E.'s father James William Fair practised from 1855 until his death in 1891.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Model T Ford in Ireland - " It was 1907 when the first Ford motor cars appeared at the Irish motor show in Dublin. By then Ford was the biggest car manufacturer in America. At that event, the Ford exhibit was the Model N, the first low priced four cylinder car to be produced by the company and was to be the direct ancestor of Ford’s most successful car, The Model T. The T began production in 1908 and continued until May 1927 when the last of the fifteen million Ts rolled off the assembly line. Interestingly, production of the T at Cork continued on until 31st December 1927. The first Irish Ford agent who started with a six car contract and the arrival of the new Model T in 1909 was an immediate success with sales doubling year on year until 1913 when they reached a level of 600 Fords sold in Ireland." From irishmodeltclub.ie/2013/01/07/ford-the-cork-connection/

comment.author: 30369211@N00

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
This looks like 'our' Major Owen-Lewis
[London Gazette, 27 September 1901]: "Arthur Francis Owen-Lewis, Lieutenant, Yorkshire Regiment. In recognition of services during the operations in South Africa". The Insignia were presented by the King 29 October 1901. He retired 25 July 1907, and became Major, Reserve of Officers, 23 January 1914. Major Owen-Lewis served in the European War, 1914-18, as GSO, Irish Command and AQMG France; was mentioned in Despatches twice, and awarded the OBE in 1918. He was appointed Inspector of Prisons for Ireland. In 1896 he married Kathleen, daughter of William Henry, of Tivoli, County Dublin. DSO, OBE (1st m), QSA (3) CC OFS Trans (Capt, York Regt), KSA (2) (Capt DSO, Yorks Regt), BWM, Victory Medal with MID (Lt Col). Spink 1964 £32. Lovell 1978 est £330. Dixon 1987 £875.
From angloboerwar.com/index.php/medals-and-awards/british/1884...

comment.author: 30369211@N00

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: IY 136 was also registered to Major Lewis in the 1911-12 . Motor Directory for County Louth 1911-12 We've come on Major Lewis before..... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/araireland/6890817343/]

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: That model T has a number painted on the radiator, which looks as if it begins with LI. LI was the reg for Westmeath: LI 1 to LI 9999 (Dec 1903 – Jun 1959). The 1911-12 Motor Directory for Westmeath gives 68 possibles. Last digit is clearly 2: 10 possibles.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Unfortunately the Motor Directory just gives reg. no. and name/address of owner. Major Lewis still listed as owner in 1915-1916 directory, which is the latest one we have.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

Could be 162 or 152 (if so, maybe registered in 1913 or at outside for our purposes, 1914) Plus what's going on with all the Westmeath cars registered to owners in England?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: I think IY 136 is a 1908 Humber tourer . Of all the Humbers here the 1908's wide angular grill is the closest match. considering the owner's Dublin address why would IY 136 be in the Louth directory?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
LI, 3 digits, ends in 2, Cars: only 3 possibilities (in 1911-12):

LI 102 Claud E. Vivian Emo House, Moate
LI 112 Otway Graham Toler Durrow Abbey, Tullamore
LI 132 Otway Graham Toler Durrow Abbey, Tullamore

And two of them belong to the same man!

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Reg numbers are given out only once: if the car is resold to someone in another county, the details are updated, just as a WH car could be sold on to someone in Dublin today.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: More Model T Ford details "Prior to the 1912 model year (when front doors were added to the touring model), US - made open cars did not have an opening door for the driver. Later models included closed cars (introduced in 1915), " From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Model_T#Design_changes ... which kind of implies the car here with an open door has to be later than 1912. Or maybe not?

Were there loads of cars written off in crashes? Phantom car theft rings?
